terms.definition: Product Requirements Document - an internal document that defines what a product should accomplish for users without specifying implementation details
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides self-service support to users
A support model where customers can find answers and solve problems independently without contacting support staff
The visual elements and interactive components through which users interact with a software application
Keep It Simple, Stupid - a design principle emphasizing simplicity and avoiding unnecessary complexity
Unique Selling Points - distinctive features or benefits that differentiate a product from competitors
A lightweight markup language that uses plain text formatting syntax to create structured documents
Enhanced search results that display additional information like ratings, images, or structured data beyond basic text
Search Engine Results Pages - the pages displayed by search engines in response to user queries
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code, allowing multiple versions to be maintained and updated
The process of adapting content, software, or documentation for specific languages, cultures, or regional markets
The overall perception and interaction a customer has with a company across all touchpoints and stages of engagement
The consistent personality, style, and emotional quality expressed in written communications and brand messaging
Brief HTML attributes that summarize webpage content and appear in search engine results below page titles
Fictional characters created to represent different user types and their goals, behaviors, and characteristics for targeted content creation
